items.message: Flooding is possible from Friday evening and overnight into Saturday morning. Heavy rain is forecast throughout Friday afternoon with intense and potentially thundery torrential periods of rain developing during Friday evening across the area. The forecast suggests that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from late evening. We expect rivers to remain high throughout Saturday morning. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Saturday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
Rising river levels throughout the morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.
Weather conditions are expected to improve this afternoon and no further flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 15/06/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 14/06/25.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley.
Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.0m to 3.5m on Saturday morning, 14/06/25.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday afternoon, 14/06/25.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 15/06/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The flood alert level is forecast to be reached at 13:00 today, Saturday 14th July.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
Following heavy thundery showers overnight, river levels are high and further showers are forecast throughout the day but no further flooding is expected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 15/06/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Flooding is expected tonight into the early hours of Saturday. Heavy rain has fallen in the area which has caused the River Dart to rise, and the river is forecast to continue rising. Properties and low lying areas around Riverside and Netherton Cottages, Staverton Bridge and Town Mills areas of Staverton, will start to flood first. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated Saturday morning or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Polegate Brook Street Stream, Wannock Mill Stream

items.message: Less than 9mm of rain was recorded at our rain gauges Friday evening. River levels only rose a small amount. Isolated, light showers might still occur at times on Saturday and Sunday. However, as forecast rainfall amounts over the weekend are now minimal, river flooding is no longer thought possible. High pressure is predicted to bring settled weather next week. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of property flooding returns.

Less than 6mm of rain was recorded at our rain gauges Friday evening. River levels only rose a small amount. Isolated, light showers might still occur at times on Saturday and Sunday. However, as forecast rainfall amounts over the weekend are now minimal, river flooding is no longer thought possible. High pressure is predicted to bring settled weather next week. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of property flooding returns.

items.description: Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Greta, St Johns Beck, Glendermackin

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Following overnight heavy rain showers, flooding is possible from low lying land and roads. Surface water may also be an issue.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around River Derwent from Keswick to Bassenthwaite. The Rivers Greta, Glenderamackin and St Johns Beck including Keswick.
Further showers, some heavy, are forecast during Saturday but no further flooding is expected, and no flood warnings are predicted.
We are closely monitoring the situation 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 15/06/2025, or as the situation changes.
